content: Is there a name for the theorem ∀ {p q : Prop}, p → q → p?
In set.mm, this is called Simp or "the principle of simplification." https://us.metamath.org/mpeuni/ax-1.html
Do you think this theorem deserves a name?
I've heard it be called "weakening" in some contexts. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monotonicity_of_entailment
I don't think we need a dedicated theorem for fun x _ ↦ x

while we're on the topic, why are the combinators deprecated? are there other functions they should be replaced by, or is the idea that they're so simple that they don't really need their own definitions?
I don't see any discussion about SKI combinators per se, but they were deprecated in #15188 by @Kim Morrison
I see... guessing it falls under "some material that was ported from Lean 3 but is used nowhere"

still a bit strange to deprecate something just because it isn't used anywhere else... usually I interpret deprecation as "there's a better way to do this" but here's it's like "the better way to do this is to not do combinatory logic in the first place" :big_smile:

but I could also charitably interpret it as "nothing else uses this, so don't expect it to be maintained" which is fair
It's fine to do combinatory logic, but some one liner definitions are not that. Removing these was just clean up of unused material that was ported unnecessarily.
I also remember that they don't work well, since there are all these implicits and universe level variables that elaboration can't solve for.
